conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light from a source, creating a silhouette on a surface.
The position and size of a shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface where the shadow is cast.
The initial image shows four objects above the slabs, illuminated by a light source positioned at the front upper right, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground to the back left of the objects.
The light source moves to the front right, away from the objects. This means it is moving diagonally forward and to the right from its initial position.

premise: Shadows move in the opposite direction of the light source's movement.
conclusion: As the light source moves to the front right, the shadows will shift backward and to the left.

premise: When the light source moves away from the objects, the shadows generally become larger due to the increased distance between the light source and the objects, causing the shadows to stretch.
conclusion: As the light source moves away, the shadows will become larger.

premise: The shadows A, B, C, and D will shift backward and to the left and become larger as the light source moves to the front right, away from the objects.
conclusion: When the light source moves to the front right, away from the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will shift backward and to the left, and they will increase in size.
